{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3295022,"name":"RD","username":"Robots9484","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/67e7ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-26T12:15:29.395Z","cooked":"

Hey, our team is searching for images and models for the notes in the limelight 3 but we don’t have the google coral can anyone help us?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-01-26T12:15:29.395Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":224,"reads":138,"readers_count":137,"score":1147.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":452116,"topic_slug":"note-model-images-configuration-limelight-3-without-google-coral","display_username":"RD","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63662,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#9484"},"post_url":"/t/note-model-images-configuration-limelight-3-without-google-coral/452116/1","custom_user_title":"#9484","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3295027,"name":null,"username":"veg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/3be4f8/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-26T12:34:33.355Z","cooked":"

The LimeLight does not support running Machine Learning models without a Coral attached. That said, DigiKey has plenty of Corals in stock for about $72, so you might consider getting one.

If you don’t want to invest in a Coral you can run ML models on a Raspberry Pi without the accelerator, but you will get very low frame rates - typically around 3fps in my experience. This can be usable, even if it doesn’t give you very tight closed-loop feedback. But in the end you’ll probably pay more for a Pi + case + voltage regulator + … than you would to just buy the Coral.

If you guys can’t get your hands on a coral, you could try the color pipeline options on the limelight.

You have to buy the coral if you want to do anything ML-related, though.

I am not sure what you are asking for. If you do not attach a Coral, the LimeLight firmware will not allow you to load and run a ML model.

I don’t think LimeLight has released anything specific to this season yet, but there are a couple of trained game piece models that people have shared here on CD that will work with it - again if you have a Coral.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-01-26T12:49:40.461Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":24.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":452116,"topic_slug":"note-model-images-configuration-limelight-3-without-google-coral","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63662,"username":"Robots9484","name":"RD","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/67e7ee/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48088,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/note-model-images-configuration-limelight-3-without-google-coral/452116/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3295033,"name":null,"username":"veg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/v/3be4f8/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-26T12:55:11.106Z","cooked":"

For more details on how to run a ML model on a vanilla Raspberry Pi, check out this documentation for pycoral. (Yes, I know the page is telling you how to use the Coral that you don’t have - bear with me…) The library can auto-detect the presence of the Coral and can run the ML model detection without it, albeit at much slower frame rates. You can use this to run a trained model without a Coral.

I hope this helps you get started. Keep asking questions!

Coral

Run inference on the Edge TPU with Python | Coral

How to use the Python TensorFlow Lite API to perform inference with Coral devices

docs.limelightvision.io

Color Thresholding | Limelight Documentation

Thresholding is a critical component of most vision tracking algorithms. It is the act of taking an image, and throwing away any pixels that aren't within a specific color range. The result of thresholding is generally a one-dimensional binary image...

There is a guide on the thresholding page from Limelight along with the rest of the documentation for it. These official sources are gonna provide the best information of how to use their product.

There isn’t a magic set of numbers we could tell you that will work for you to see a Note it’s something you tweak in real time until it’s filtered to just the color you are looking for and then lock those values in. More than likely you will have to calibrate at the events as your lab lighting is going to be different than the field lighting
